facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 220 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 220 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment, and order dated August 4, 1960, of the Punjab High Court, in Criminal Revision No. 31-D of 1960. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, R. H. Dhebar and D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 4, 1960 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 31-D of 1960.

facts.text: J. R. Mudholkar, J. delivered a separate judgment.

anchor.surface_text: J. R. Mudholkar, J., delivered a separate judgment. RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-The only point for companysideration in this appeal, by certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature at Punjab, is whether a police officer

facts.text: Ram Singh was suspected of having committed an offence under s. 8 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Singh, respondent, was suspected of having companymitted an offence under s. 8 of the Act. Jet Ram, Sub-Inspector, who had number been appointed a special police officer by the State Government, investigated the case and submitted the charge- sheet to the Magistrate.

facts.text: Jet Ram, Sub-Inspector, not appointed special police officer, investigated the case.

anchor.surface_text: Jet Ram, Sub-Inspector, who had number been appointed a special police officer by the State Government, investigated the case and submitted the charge- sheet to the Magistrate. The Magistrate quashed the charge- sheet, holding that the special police officer alone

facts.text: Jet Ram submitted charge-sheet to the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: investigated the case and submitted the charge- sheet to the Magistrate. The Magistrate quashed the charge- sheet, holding that the special police officer alone was companypetent to investigate the case and that Jet Ram companyld number have investigated it.

facts.text: Magistrate quashed the charge-sheet holding only special police officer competent to investigate.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate quashed the charge- sheet, holding that the special police officer alone was companypetent to investigate the case and that Jet Ram companyld number have investigated it. On revision by the State, the High Court agreed with the view of the Magistrate

facts.text: State filed revision, High Court agreed with Magistrate and dismissed revision.

anchor.surface_text: On revision by the State, the High Court agreed with the view of the Magistrate and dismissed the revision. The High Court, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and hence this appeal by the Delhi Administration.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and hence this appeal by the Delhi Administration. The learned Solicitor-General, appearing for the Delhi Administration, has submitted that

facts.text: Appeal by Delhi Administration.

anchor.surface_text: hence this appeal by the Delhi Administration. The learned Solicitor-General, appearing for the Delhi Administration, has submitted that in the absence of any definite provision in the Act de-barring the police to exercise its powers

facts.text: Act enacted in pursuance of International Convention signed at New York on 9th May 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the merits of the question for determination, we may set out the object of the enactment and the relevant provisions thereof. The Act was enacted in pursuance of the International Convention signed at New York on the 9th day of May, 1950

facts.text: Investigation into offences made by officer-in-charge of Kamla Market Police Station.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is alleged to be a pimp and said to have companymitted offences under s. 8 of the Act. Inves- tigation into the offences was made by the officer-incharge of the Kamla Market Police Station and a charge-sheet was presented by him before a First Class Magistrate in Delhi.

facts.text: Charge-sheet presented before First Class Magistrate in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: a charge-sheet was presented by him before a First Class Magistrate in Delhi. Similar charge-sheets were put up against certain other persons. An objection was taken before the Magistrate in all these cases that the charge-sheets were bad

facts.text: Similar charge-sheets against other persons, objection taken that investigation not by special police officer.

anchor.surface_text: Similar charge-sheets were put up against certain other persons. An objection was taken before the Magistrate in all these cases that the charge-sheets were bad because the investigation into the various offences was number made by the special police officer

facts.text: Magistrate upheld objection and rejected charge-sheets.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was upheld by the Magistrate and the charge-sheets were rejected. An application for revision was preferred by the Delhi Administration before the High Court of Punjab.

facts.text: Delhi Administration filed revision before Punjab High Court, which was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: An application for revision was preferred by the Delhi Administration before the High Court of Punjab. But that application was also rejected. Thereupon the Administration sought a certificate from the High Court under Art. 134 1  c

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Administration sought a certificate from the High Court under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution which the High Court granted. That is how the present appeal came to be preferred before this Court.

facts.text: High Court followed decision in Kuppammal, In re, I.L.R. 1959 Mad. 345.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following the decision in Kuppammal, In re  1  held that an offence under the Act must be investigated only by one of the officers mentioned in s. 13 and that a charge-sheet based upon the investigation

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by majority.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the special police officer is companypetent to investigate and that he and his assistant police officers are the only persons companypetent to investigate offences under the Act ... The result is that this appeal by the Delhi Administration fails and is hereby dismissed.

facts.text: Mudholkar J. would allow the appeal and remit case to Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this view, therefore, I would allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and of the Magistrate and remit the case to the latter for being dealt with according to law.
certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and hence this appeal by the Delhi Administration.

issues.text: whether a police officer, who is neither a special police officer under the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956 (Act CIV of 1956), hereinafter called the Act, nor a police officer subordinate to a special police officer, can validly investigate the offences under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The only point for consideration in this appeal, by certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature at Punjab, is whether a police officer, who is neither a special police officer under the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956 (Act CIV of 1956), hereinafter called the Act, nor a police officer subordinate

issues.text: whether the expression 'dealing with offences under this Act' in Section 13(1) of the Act includes the power to investigate offences thereunder

anchor.surface_text: According to s. 13 of the Act, there shall be, for each area to be specified by the State Government, a special police officer appointed by or on behalf of that Government for dealing with offences under the Act in that area. The expression dealing with offences is of wide import and will include any act which the police has to do in connection with the offences under the Act.

issues.text: whether offences under the Act are to be investigated according to the provisions of the CrPC subject to the Act regulating the manner of investigation

anchor.surface_text: s. 5 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which reads All offences under the Indian Penal Code shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the provisions hereinafter contained.

anchor.surface_text: MUDHOLKAR, J.-The point which arises for consideration in this appeal is whether a charge-sheet presented by a station-house officer alleging against the respondent certain offences under the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956 (Act No. CIV of 1956) (hereinafter called the Act) is bad because the investigation

issues.text: whether the Act constitutes a complete code regulating investigation of its offences to the exclusion of regular police powers under CrPC

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the various provisions that the Act is a complete Code with respect to what is to be done under it. It deals with the suppression of immoral traffic in women and girls, a matter which has to be tackled with consideration, intelligence and understanding of the problem.

holdings.text: the special police officer is competent to investigate and that he and his assistant police officers are the only persons competent to investigate offences under the Act and that police officers not specially appointed as special police officers cannot investigate the offences under the Act even though they are cognizable offences

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the special police officer is companypetent to investigate and that he and his assistant police officers are the only persons companypetent to investigate offences under the Act and that police officers number specially appointed as special police officers cannot investigate the offences under the Act even though they are cognizable offences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act constitutes complete code with exclusive machinery for special police officer; specific provisions on arrest, search, removal limit powers to special officer and subordinates; CrPC s.5 applies subject to special enactment regulating manner; duplication undesirable

holdings.text: the Act is a complete Code with respect to what is to be done under it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act creates offences, provides forum, adopts/modifies CrPC provisions, appoints special machinery with advisory body; implies new machinery deals with offences exclusively

holdings.text: The expression dealing with offences is of wide import and will include any act which the police has to do in connection with the offences under the Act

anchor.surface_text: According to s. 13 of the Act, there shall be, for each area to be specified by the State Government, a special police officer appointed by or on behalf of that Government for dealing with offences under the Act in that area. holdings.text: All offences under any other law shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the same provisions, but subject to any enactment for the time being in force regulating the manner or place of investigating, inquiring into, trying or otherwise dealing with such offences

anchor.surface_text: s. 5 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which reads All offences under the Indian Penal Code shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the provisions hereinafter companytained. holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses lower courts' view consistent with exclusive machinery under Act

holdings.text: In my opinion the view taken by the Madras High Court and accepted by the Punjab High Court is untenable

In my opinion the view taken by the Madras High Court and accepted by the Punjab High Court is untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express provision in s.13(1) confers exclusive investigation power on special PO; CrPC s.156 applies to SHO for cognizable offences; s.5 CrPC not abrogated

anchor.surface_text: MUDHOLKAR, J.-The point which arises for companysideration in this appeal is whether a charge-sheet presented by a station-house officer alleging against the respondent certain offences under the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956  Act No. CIV of 1956   hereinafter called the Act  is bad because the investigation into those offences was carried out number by a special police officer appointed under the Act but by the station house officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects exclusivity; SHO has power under CrPC s.156(1); no regulation of manner excluding it

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following the decision in Kuppammal, In re  1  held that an offence under the Act must be investigated only by one of the officers mentioned in s. 13 and that a charge-sheet based upon the investigation made by any other police officer is bad and must be quashed.

precedents.cited_proposition: an offence under the Act must be investigated only by one of the officers mentioned in s. 13 and that a charge-sheet based upon the investigation made by any other police officer is bad and must be quashed

anchor.surface_text: In addition it provides for the making of rules. I.L.R. 1959 Mad. 345.
